quote: [A] calm desperation came over her. She braced herself, physically and mentally.
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: [B]eing an unmarried woman, with the handicap of my sex, my first acquaintance with crime will probably be my last. Indeed, it came near enough to being my last acquaintance with anything.
author: Mary Roberts Rinehart
title: The Circular Staircase

quote: [C]onstancy was no virtue in her eyes; she did not possess it herself and she valued it little in others.
author: Jessie Fauset
title: Plum Bun: A Novel Without a Moral

quote: [H]er children were captives - and her heart was broken. You know the rest . . . .
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Hope Leslie, or, Early Times in the Massachusetts

quote: [H]er erect attitude, her free and lofty tread, and the perfect composure of her countenance, all expressed the courage and dignity of her soul.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Hope Leslie, or, Early Times in the Massachusetts

quote: [H]er manner forbade any mention of the night before.
author: Mary Roberts Rinehart
title: Tish

quote: [I]f you should feel the need of exercise, don't gad in the streets. Remember there is nothing like a broom and a dust-pan to make the blood circulate.
author: Fanny Fern
title: Ruth Hall: A Domestic Tale or the Present Time

quote: [I]ndeed, the ignorant and superstitious believed her to possess the 'evil eye,' and to be gifted with 'second sight.'
author: E.D.E.N. Southworth
title: The Hidden Hand or, Capitola the Madcap

quote: [I]t was pervading her entire being, running along her nerves with a strange thrill, mounting to and bewildering her brain.
author: Lois Nichols Waisbrooker
title: Nothing Like It, Or Steps to the Kingdom

quote: [M]istaking enthusiasm for inspiration, she attempted every branch of art with youthful audacity.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: [P]erhaps it was some fault in her own disposition, concentrated and egotistic as she was, but certainly she felt no pangs of separation, no fear of her future.
author: Jessie Redmon Fauset
title: The Sleeper Wakes
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: [S]he did not cry. She did not, of course, realize that she was to stay here indefinitely, but if she had, even at that age she would hardly have shed tears, she was always too eager, too curious to know, to taste what was going to happen next.
author: Jessie Redmon Fauset
title: The Sleeper Wakes
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: [S]he fell to thinking that all the wonderful happenings in her sheltered, pampered life had come to her through her beauty. . . . She was right.
author: Jessie Redmon Fauset
title: The Sleeper Wakes
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: [S]he seemed to live in a happy world of her own, only venturing out to meet the few whom she trusted and loved.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: [S]he was aware that, to her, security was the most important and desired thing in life. Not for any of the others, or for all of them, would she exchange it.
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: [S]he was beloved--she loved again--and she had rashly dashed away the happiness within her grasp.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Hope Leslie, or, Early Times in the Massachusetts

quote: [S]he will wish to have lived when she comes to die.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Married or Single?

quote: [T]he darkness so terrified her that she made a lattice of her fingers, and slowly opened her eyes on the lesser horror.
author: Dorothy West
title: Funeral
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: [T]he promise of the bud fulfilled in the rose. Time has only beautified her; for happiness is his antagonist and has gained the mastery.
author: S. Alice Callahan
title: Wynema: A Child of the Forest

quote: [T]he unhappy girl pressed her hands to her forehead, as if to keep together her distracted thoughts.
author: María Amparo Ruiz de Burton
title: The Squatter and the Don

quote: [T]he young daughter of Lew Wing, is as bold and free in her ways as are the white women, and her name is on all the men's tongues. What prudent man of our race would take her as a wife?
author: Edith Maude Eaton
title: The Wisdom of the New," Mrs. Spring Fragrance

quote: [T]he younger girl loved the sudden, mystic hush which seemed to descend on the congregation.
author: Jessie Fauset
title: Plum Bun: A Novel Without a Moral

quote: [T]hree girls lavishly dressed in colored silks, with their black hair plastered back from their faces and heavily bejewelled behind, chirped and chattered in a gilded balcony above them like birds in a cage.
author: Edith Maude Eaton
title: The Wisdom of the New," Mrs. Spring Fragrance

quote: [W]e are taught by books, by all the talk we hear from old and young, married and single, that marriage is not only the felicity of woman, but that her diginity, her attractiveness, her usefulness depends on it. . . .
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Married or Single?

quote: [W]ere I a man, it would be so sweet to use my powers to defend the defenseless. It would seem to me so impossible to use that power to echo the faintest rumor adverse to a woman, or to keep cowardly silence in the shrugging, sneering, slanderer's presence, when a bold word of mine for the cause of right, might close his dastard lips.
author: Fanny Fern
title: Ruth Hall: A Domestic Tale or the Present Time

quote: [W]omen forget all those things they don't want to remember, and remember everything they don't want to forget. The dream is the truth.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: [Y]ou won't be able to keep from loving her; she has the sweetest and saddest face I ever saw. I have read of the woman with a story written on her face, but I never believed it anything but a fairy tale.
author: Pauline E. Hopkins
title: Contending Forces: A Romance Illustrative of Negro Life North and South

quote: A dark figure with a babe in her arms creeps stealthily from a tent into the dark night. Softly and steathily it steps until it reaches the outskirts of the reservation, where it is met by other dark figures, some with the papoose, some without.
author: S. Alice Callahan
title: Wynema: A Child of the Forest

quote: A little war of defense for helpless things was going on inside her.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: A mother, encircled by healthful sporting children, is always a beautiful spectacle.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Hope Leslie, or, Early Times in the Massachusetts

quote: A weary smile flickered across her face as she sat there on the ground like a bronze figure of patience and long-suffering.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: The Widespread Enigma Concerning Blue-Star Woman," American Indian Stories

quote: A woman who deals in poison cannot be trusted, whatever she says.
author: Mary Ellen Bamford
title: Father Lambert's Family: A Story of Old-Time France

quote: A woman with a conscience often makes a burnt-offering of her heart, from pure altruism.
author: Lilian Lida Bell
title: The Under Side of Things

quote: About her clung that dim suggestion of polite insolence with which a few women are born and which some acquire with the coming of riches or importance.
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: Alert for any sound of footfalls nigh, she holds her breath to listen. Her right hand rests on a long knife in her belt.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: A Warrior's Daughter," American Indian Stories

quote: Amazingly her beauty availed her nothing.
author: Jessie Redmon Fauset
title: The Sleeper Wakes
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: And again she let herself dwell on the fallaciousness of a social system which stretched appearance so far beyond being.
author: Jessie Fauset
title: Plum Bun: A Novel Without a Moral

quote: And did too much striving, too much faith in safety and permancence, unfit one for these other things?
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: As she spoke of the past she suddenly became mad again, and for hours I fought with her.
author: Kate Langley Bosher
title: The House of Happiness

quote: At such times she would plunge into a round of reckless gayety and try to forget for the time being her unsatisfied longing and love.
author: Winnifred Eaton
title: Miss Numè of Japan: A Japanese-American Romance

quote: At this crisis of her life, she was in danger of resigning the control of this element to another in whose hands it would be sure to become a destructive agent.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Married or Single?

quote: Beautiful--of deep-rooted intelligence handicapped by inadequate schooling, a pagan love for the gorgeous wonders of Nature and a passion for all things artistic.
author: Maude Irwin Owens
title: Bathesda of Sinners Run
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: By a supreme effort she held back her tears, but it was years before she forgot the picture of her mother sitting back in the old Morris chair, composing herself for death.
author: Jessie Fauset
title: Plum Bun: A Novel Without a Moral

quote: By motherhood they were born and by motherhood they lived--life was, to them, just the long cycle of motherhood.
author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
title: Herland

quote: Death triumphant and mighty had no fears for her.
author: Jessie Fauset
title: Plum Bun: A Novel Without a Moral

quote: Deep within her was an abiding ambition to see her race perpetuated. Though she felt that her talents were of a high order, she knew she would escape greatness through her lack of early training.
author: Dorothy West
title: Prologue to a Life
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: Did I understand you to say that the Negro woman in her native state is truly a virtuous woman?
author: Pauline E. Hopkins
title: Contending Forces: A Romance Illustrative of Negro Life North and South

quote: Don't shut yourself up in a bandbox because you are a woman, but understand what is going on, and educate yourself to take your part in the world's work, for it all affects you and yours.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: Each girl, of course, was reared in full knowledge of her Crowning Office, and they had, even then, very high ideas of the molding powers of the mother, as well as those of education.
author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
title: Herland

quote: Everybody liked her, for among her good gifts was tact.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: Five streams of life, pouring into her sick veins, fierce, tumultuous, until the poison and the pain burst into rivulets of sweat that ran swift and long down her quivering body, and presently left her washed and clean and quiet and very, very tired.
author: Dorothy West
title: Prologue to a Life
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: Fond as we are of our girls, we must not let our affection for them cloud our vision as to what is wisest and best for their future welfare.
author: Anzia Yezierska
title: Arrogant Beggar

quote: For a moment she stood puzzled and helpless. Something she did not understand was troubling, something in which she could not help.
author: Kate Langley Bosher
title: How It Happened

quote: For the first time in many years the tired woman rested, body and heart and brain.
author: Isabella Macdonald Alden
title: The King's Daughter

quote: For the first time she suffered and rebelled because she was unable to disregard the burden of race. It was, she cried silently, enough to suffer as a woman, an individual, on one's own account, without having to suffer for the race as well.
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: For your Creole girls are proud, and would die rather than let the world see their sorrows.
author: Alice Dunbar Nelson
title: The Goodness of Saint Rocque," The Goodness of St. Rocque, and Other Stories

quote: From her unerring long knife the enemy falls heavily at her feet.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: A Warrior's Daughter," American Indian Stories

quote: From now on until death she was going to have flower dust and springtime sprinkled over everything.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: Gradually she began to comprehend, and she stood motionless, listening, her pale lips firmly compressed, her eyes only showing her agitation and how grieved she was; their dark-blue was almost black, and they glowed like stars.
author: María Amparo Ruiz de Burton
title: The Squatter and the Don

quote: Growing up as the average colored American girl does grow up, surrounded by types of every hue, color and facial configuration she had had no absolute ideal. She was not even aware that there was one.
author: Jessie Redmon Fauset
title: The Sleeper Wakes
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: Her childish faith in her elders was not conditioned by a knowledge of human limitations, but thought all things possible to grown-ups.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: A Warrior's Daughter," American Indian Stories

quote: Her face had beamed with the pleasure of doing good.
author: Anzia Yezierska
title: Arrogant Beggar

quote: Her old thoughts were going to come in handy now, but new words would have to be made and said to fit them.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: Her unselfish zeal never flagged. She flitted from one want to another as naturally as she breathed and with as little consciousness of the process.
author: Lilian Lida Bell
title: The Love of Affairs of an Old Maid

quote: Her year abroad has lengthened into several years, and they have been the most beautiful of her life . . . .
author: Lilian Lida Bell
title: The Love of Affairs of an Old Maid

quote: I did not admire clever business women, as I had usually found them, and so had other girls of my acquaintence, not nearly so kind-hearted, generous, and helpful as the humble drudges of the world - the ordinary working woman.
author: Edith Maude Eaton
title: The Story of One White Woman who Married a Chinese," Mrs. Spring Fragrance

quote: I don't even remember of feeling 'drunk.' What kind of a feeling is it?
author: S. Alice Callahan
title: Wynema: A Child of the Forest

quote: I loved her because she gave up so much of herself. But I knew I could never never be like that.
author: Anzia Yezierska
title: Arrogant Beggar

quote: I was as free as the wind that blew my hair, and no less spirited than a bounding deer.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: Impressions of an Indian Childhood," American Indian Stories

quote: If only women could bring into their homes this self-sacrificing attitude toward life! Isn't just as satisfying to the soul to feel you have scrubbed a floor faithfully as to be mistress of the house?
author: Anzia Yezierska
title: Arrogant Beggar

quote: If you feel you are right, dear girl, stand for the uplifting of the race and womanhood. Do not shrink from duty.
author: Pauline E. Hopkins
title: Contending Forces: A Romance Illustrative of Negro Life North and South

quote: In her hands committees were as wax, and loud murmurings against the tyranny of her rule died down to judicious whispers.
author: Pauline E. Hopkins
title: Contending Forces: A Romance Illustrative of Negro Life North and South

quote: In my opinion, no kind-hearted girl ought to desire to be loved except by the one she loves.
author: María Amparo Ruiz de Burton
title: The Squatter and the Don

quote: In spite of their demonstrative manners, American girls are very nice when one knows them.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: In the divine unconsciousness of innocent childhood she comforted the pure and the guilty woman alike.
author: Lilian Lida Bell
title: A Little Sister to the Wilderness

quote: In this country, she is most happy who has no child, . . . .
author: Edith Maude Eaton
title: The Wisdom of the New," Mrs. Spring Fragrance

quote: Intuitions are given to women, not because they are the weaker sex, but because they are the mothers of the world, and they are thus given the strongest protection against unseen and unseeable evils.
author: Lilian Lida Bell
title: Angela's Quest

quote: It gained her nothing, however, to pronounce her name to the government official to whom she applied for her share of tribal land.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: The Widespread Enigma Concerning Blue-Star Woman," American Indian Stories

quote: It had seemed to me nothing on earth could be as terrible as to grow so old and bent. And yet she could smile like that.
author: Anzia Yezierska
title: Arrogant Beggar

quote: It was a glorious thing for a girl, she said, wasn't it, to be associated with such a life as that?
author: Edith Wharton
title: The Portait," The Greater Inclination

quote: It was doubtless intuition of the quick, vivacious sort which belonged to her blood that served her.
author: Alice Dunbar Nelson
title: Sister Josepha," The Goodness of St. Rocque, and Other Stories

quote: It was her one, eager, passionate longing, in those childish days, that these locks of hers should be let to grow. She thought she could almost bear anything else, if only this stiff, unseemly crop might lengthen out to waves and ringlets that should toss in the wind like the carefully kempt tresses of children she met in the streets.
author: Adeline Dutton Train Whitney
title: Faith Gartney's Girlhood

quote: It was impossible for her daughter to forget that a woman of intellectual power could be the most successful of mothers.
author: Elizabeth Stuart Phelps
title: Chapters from a Life

quote: It was thought she might be eclipsed by the younger and more brilliant women students on the strength of their alma mater, but she still held her own by sheer force of will-power and indomitable pluck.
author: Pauline E. Hopkins
title: Contending Forces: A Romance Illustrative of Negro Life North and South

quote: Like most women of futile lives she lacked a sense of proportion . . . .
author: Mary Roberts Rinehart
title: Dangerous Days

quote: Looking out into space, she saw the nodding sunflowers, and they acquiesced to her.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: The Widespread Enigma Concerning Blue-Star Woman," American Indian Stories

quote: Lying there, with nothing in sight but the leafy branches of the trees high above her head, through which gleams of the deep blue sky came softly, she felt as if she had left the world, and was floating, Ariel-like, in mid-air.
author: Pauline E. Hopkins
title: Hagar's Daughter: A Story of Southern Caste Prejudice
publisher: The Magazine Novels of Pauline Hopkins

quote: Money, position, fashionable accomplishments, and elegant manners, were most desirable things in her eyes, and she liked to associate with those who possessed them; often mistaking the false for the true, and admiring what is not admirable.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: Mother-love with them was not a brute passion, a mere "instinct," a wholly personal feeling; it was--a religion.
author: Charlotte Perkins Gilman
title: Herland

quote: Natalie had everything. The portrait showed it. It was beautiful, smug, complacent.
author: Mary Roberts Rinehart
title: Dangerous Days

quote: Nestled into her bed of sweet-scented grass, she dozed away into another dream. Still the guardian star in the sky beamed compassionatedly down upon the little tepee on the plain.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: The Trial Path," American Indian Stories

quote: Never forgetting that by birth she was a gentlewoman, she cultivated her aristocratic tastes and feelings, so that when the opportunity came, she might be ready to take the place from which poverty now excluded her.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: Now that the period of novitiate was over, it was just beginning to dawn upon her that she had made a mistake.
author: Alice Dunbar Nelson
title: Sister Josepha," The Goodness of St. Rocque, and Other Stories

quote: Of course she was being unconscionably idle; but as her days were filled to overflowing with the impact of new impressions, this signified nothing.
author: Jessie Fauset
title: Plum Bun: A Novel Without a Moral

quote: Often she was sad and silent, at which times her full arched lips were compressed into hard bitter lines, and shadows fell under her black eyes. Then I clung to her hand and begged to know what made the tears fall.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: Impressions of an Indian Childhood," American Indian Stories

quote: Once again her dangerous sense of humor threatened her.
author: Mary Roberts Rinehart
title: K

quote: Outside the long sweet march music of many bands floated in as if in mockery, and the flash of rockets and Bengal lights illuminated the dead, white face of the girl troubadour.
author: Alice Dunbar Nelson
title: A Carnival Jangle," The Goodness of St. Rocque, and Other Stories

quote: Quite suddenly she knew she was going to run away. . . . Not that she was the least bit unhappy but because she must get out in the world,--she felt caged, imprisoned.
author: Jessie Redmon Fauset
title: The Sleeper Wakes
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: Race! The thing that bound and suffocated her. Whatever steps she took, or if she took none at all, something would be crushed.
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: Ruth felt as if wings were growing from her shoulders.
author: Fanny Fern
title: Ruth Hall: A Domestic Tale or the Present Time

quote: Security. Was it just a word? If not, then was it only by the sacrifice of other things, happiness, love, or some wild ecstacy that she had never known, that it could be obtained?
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: Several times during the day, she found herself at the broken mirror, arranging and rearranging her dark mass of unkempt hair with fumbling fingers.
author: Anzia Yezierska
title: Wings
publisher: How I Found America: Collected Stories of Anzia Yezierska

quote: She always let a lock of hair hang over one eye, so that the favorite aunt might brush it away with a caressing hand and kiss her forehead.
author: Dorothy West
title: Funeral
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: She and her children have eggs and buttered rolls for breakfast each morning like millionaires.
author: Anzia Yezierska
title: The Fat of the Land
publisher: How I Found America: Collected Stories of Anzia Yezierska

quote: She belonged in this land of rising towers. She was an American. She grew from this soil, and she would not be uprooted.
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: She came in as she would have entered any other drawing-room on any other occasion -- neither bold, nor timid.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Married or Single?

quote: She came suddenly to herself, however, and darted off, with her face as bright a crimson as her hair was golden . . . .
author: Adeline Dutton Train Whitney
title: Faith Gartney's Girlhood

quote: She can be happy who takes all and gives nothing.
author: Edith Maude Eaton
title: The Wisdom of the New

quote: She caught the glad tidings and was thrilled with new hope for her people.
author: Zitkála-Šá
title: A Dream," American Indian Stories

quote: She clasped her knees loosely with her hands, and the flames danced merrily up and down before her blurred eyes.
author: Kate Langley Bosher
title: Bobbie

quote: She clutched at her throat like one stifled for want of air.
author: Anzia Yezierska
title: Wings
publisher: How I Found America: Collected Stories of Anzia Yezierska

quote: She could weep in the midst of her happiness, hearing that endless prayer.
author: Julia Evelyn Ditto Young
title: The Story of Saville: Told in Numbers

quote: She did not reach outside for anything, nor did the things of death reach inside to disturb her calm.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: She did not talk to people as if they were strange hard shells she had to crack open to get inside. She talked as if she were already in the shell. In their very shell.
author: Marita Bonner
title: Nothing New
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: She felt herself beset with difficulties too evasive to be fought by so direct a temperament.
author: Edith Wharton
title: A Journey," The Greater Inclination

quote: She felt somewhat like a woman who in a moment of passion is betrayed into an act of infidelity, and realizes the significance of the act without being wholly awakened from its glamour.
author: Kate Chopin
title: The Awakening

quote: She followed the pathway that was formed by the myriad dust-particles, whirling in dizzy vortices like shifting sands of gold.
author: Mary Ella Waller
title: The Rose-bush of Hildesheim: A Cathedral Story

quote: She found herself the centre of sympathetic eyes.
author: Edith Wharton
title: A Journey," The Greater Inclination

quote: She got so she received all things with the stolidness of the earth which soaks up urine and perfume with the same indifference.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: She had a curious sense of freedom in these days, a feeling that at last her brain, her senses were liberated from some hateful clinging thralldom.
author: Jessie Redmon Fauset
title: The Sleeper Wakes
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: She had an inside and an outside now and suddenly she knew how not to mix them.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: She had been summoned to behold a revelation.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: She had burnt incense to "Mother" and besought the aid of the goddess of children; but her prayers would not avail, . . . .
author: Edith Maude Eaton
title: The Gift of Little Me," Mrs. Spring Fragrance

quote: She had come among the barenesss and sordidness of this neighborhood five years ago, robed in crape, and crying with great sobs that seemed to shake the vitality out of her.
author: Alice Dunbar Nelson
title: Little Miss Sophie," The Goodness of St. Rocque, and Other Stories

quote: She had come to believe that the dogs in the street howled as she passed them by, and every glance at her face was a blow, and her every breath was a cry!
author: Julia Evelyn Ditto Young
title: The Story of Saville: Told in Numbers

quote: She had cried bitterly at first because she could not have her own bed; but childhood soon forgets, and now she was sleeping soundly.
author: Lois Nichols Waisbrooker
title: Mayweed Blossoms

quote: She had done her best. The day was over and now she must go--go away from this refuge that she had learned to love, this home, hers no longer.
author: Georgia Douglas Johnson
title: Free
originalPublisher: Unknown Source, The Library of Congress, Harmon Foundation Files
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: She had dropped the cloak of a hardened, held-over youth, and taken on the ethereal robe of an inner beauty--a soul transformation had taken place.
author: Maude Irwin Owens
title: Bathesda of Sinners Run
publisher: The Sleeper Wakes: Harlem Rennaissance Stories by Women

quote: She had her girlish ambitions and hopes, and felt some disappointment at the humble way in which the new life must begin.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: She had shown, as a girl, little fondness for society, nor had she seemed to regret it during the year they had spent in the country.
author: Edith Wharton
title: The Touchstone

quote: She had spoken calmly and firmly; but her face was pallid to the hue of death, and the light which flashed from her eyes was scorching in its intensity.
author: Lois Nichols Waisbrooker
title: Helen Harlow's Vow

quote: She has a way of getting an idea and letting it simmer on the back of her brain, as you may say, when nobody knows it's been cooking at all, and then suddenly bringing it out cooked and seasoned and ready to serve.
author: Mary Roberts Rinehart
title: Tish

quote: She has access now to those that she could not reach, were she to try to work with such as call themselves Christians.
author: Lois Nichols Waisbrooker
title: Nothing Like It, Or Steps to the Kingdom

quote: She is intelligent enough, but in a contest between instinct and brains, she always follows her instinct.
author: Mary Roberts Rinehart
title: Tish

quote: She is lovely, intelligent, refined; often more so than the one who occupies the place of mistress.
author: Lois Nichols Waisbrooker
title: Nothing Like It, Or Steps to the Kingdom

quote: She is not like her naughty sister Rachel, who won't do anything but read, and never loves anybody but herself.
author: Lilian Lida Bell
title: The Love of Affairs of an Old Maid

quote: She is so deeply stamped by nature, that neither time nor custom will wear out the impression.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Married or Single?

quote: She is the sort of woman who knows how to rule well; in fact, I rather like it, for she winds one round her finger as softly and prettily as a skein of silk, and makes you feel as if she was doing you a favour all the while.
author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Little Women or Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy
currentCutation: Sampson Low, Marston, Low, and Searle

quote: She knew now how it could be, when every door of hope seemed shut, by those who make long prayers and wrap themselves in morality as with a garment, and cry with closed purses and averted faces, . . . .

title: Ruth Hall: A Domestic Tale or the Present Time

quote: She knew now that marriage did not make love.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: She lived one of those rich and pitious lives such as only gifted women knew; torn by the civil war of the dual nature which can be given to women only.
author: Elizabeth Stuart Phelps
title: Chapters from a Life

quote: She lost her soul.
author: Kate Langley Bosher
title: People Like That

quote: She made the common mistake of believing that she was the only witness for God in the place.

quote: She made up her mind to swoon even before she received the tidings.
author: Anita Scott Coleman

quote: She managed to escape at length, and, reeling from weakness and despair, she had fallen in the street; and it was thus that we found her.

quote: She may prove something very different from the pretty shallowness she seems.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick

quote: She might have made us all love her, and help to make her old age cheerful; but now, unless she repents, she will live miserably, and die forsaken, for nobody can love her with such a temper.
author: Fanny Fern
title: Ruth Hall: A Domestic Tale or the Present Time

quote: She neither frowned nor smiled when the time came that she was obliged to move; she simply moved, with as unconcerned and indifferent a face as she had worn all the time.

quote: She opened her lips as if to question; when her eye caught sight of the pale, still form, and she remained silent.
author: Lois Nichols Waisbrooker

quote: She pulled in her horizon like a great fish-net. Pulled it from around the waist of the world and draped it over her shoulder. So much of life in its meshes! She called in her soul to come and see.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: She sat up stiffly, staring out at the dawn.
author: Edith Wharton
title: A Journey," The Greater Inclination

quote: She sat with her head inclined downward, in a listening and meditative posture.
author: Catharine Maria Sedgwick
title: Married or Single?

quote: She scarcely kept the flickering life in her pale little body by the unceasing toil of a pair of bony hands, stitiching, stitching, ceaselessly, wearingly, on the bands and pockets of trousers. It was her bread, . . . it was her only hope of life.
author: Alice Dunbar Nelson
title: Little Miss Sophie," The Goodness of St. Rocque, and Other Stories

quote: She seemed to me like a gush of sunshine and song pervading a bed of violets.
author: Lois Nichols Waisbrooker
title: Nothing Like It, Or Steps to the Kingdom

quote: She seemed unaware of any danger or uncaring.
author: Nella Larsen
title: Passing

quote: She seems absorbed, silent, thoughtful, sad, and--and--you know what I fear. She says she is not sick, then it is some mental trouble, I am sure.
author: María Amparo Ruiz de Burton
title: The Squatter and the Don

quote: She set the example that day by going out on a flat rock in the lake and preparing to think all the things she'd been waiting most of her life to consider.
author: Mary Roberts Rinehart
title: Tish

quote: She stood there until something fell off the shelf inside her. Then she went inside there to see what it was.
author: Zora Neale Hurston
title: Their Eyes Were Watching God

quote: She struggled to avert her look, but her eyes refused to move and her head seemed to be held in a vice.

title: A Journey," The Greater Inclination

quote: She took her luxuries as the birds of the air take light and sunshine.

quote: She took to writing sensation stories--for in those dark ages, even all-perfect America read rubbish.

quote: She tried in a blind, hopeless way to do her duty, secretly rebelling against it all the while, for it seemed unjust that her few joys should be lessened, her burdens made heavier, and life get harder and harder as she toiled along.
author: Louisa May Alcott

quote: She turned her face upward, and a low cry of delight broke from her.

quote: She turned wrongside out just standing there and feeling.

quote: She turns away with a sinking heart, but will not give it up . . . .

quote: She was a pretty girl in a white dress and bore no traces in her face of any stern religious proclivities.

quote: She was a woman now - a very young one, it is true, but full of all a woman's witchery and grace.

quote: She was caught between two allegiances, different, yet the same. Herself. Her race.

quote: She was doing all she could to make them happy. She made no demands, none. But when she asked for something that meant more than life to her, it was refused, of course.

quote: She was less the alluring woman than the burning exultant spirit, cased in a woman's body and shining through it like a light through a transparent shell.

quote: She was living in bad society; and imaginary though it was, its influence affected her, for she was feeding heart and fancy on dangerous and unsubstantial food, and was fast brushing the innocent bloom from her nature by a premature acquaintance with the darker side of life, . . . .
